div.p: She Stoops to Conquer: OR, The Miſtakes of a Night.
She Stoops to Conquer: OR, The Miſtakes of a Night. A COMEDY. AS IT IS ACTED AT THE THEATRE-ROYAL IN COVENT-GARDEN. WRITTEN BY Doctor GOLDSMITH.
LONDON: Printed for F. NEWBERY, in St. Paul's Church-Yard. MDCCLXXIII.

div.head: To SAMUEL JOHNSON, L. L. D.
div.p: BY inſcribing this ſlight performance to you, I do not mean ſo much to compliment you as myſelf. It may do me ſome honour to inform the public, that I have lived many years in intimacy with you. It may ſerve the intereſts of mankind alſo to inform them, that the greateſt wit may be found in a character, without impairing the moſt unaffected piety.

I have, particularly, reaſon to thank you for your partiality to this performance. The undertaking a comedy, not merely ſentimental, was very dangerous; and Mr. Colman, who ſaw this piece in its various ſtages, always thought it ſo. However I ventured to truſt it to the public; and though it was neceſſarily delayed till late in the ſeaſon, I have every reaſon to be grateful.

closer.signed: I am, Dear Sir, Your moſt ſincere friend, And admirer, OLIVER GOLDSMITH.

div.head: PROLOGUE
div.stage: Enter Mr. WOODWARD, Dreſſed in Black, and holding a Handkerchief to his Eyes.

lg.l: EXCUSE me, Sirs, I pray—I can't yet ſpeak—
I'm crying now—and have been all the week!
'Tis not alone this mourning ſuit, good maſters;
I've that within—for which there are no plaiſters!
Pray wou'd you know the reaſon why I'm crying?
The Comic muſe, long ſick, is now a dying!
And if ſhe goes, my tears will never ſtop;
For as a play'r, I can't ſqueeze out one drop:
I am undone, that's all—ſhall loſe my bread—
I'd rather, but that's nothing—loſe my head.
When the ſweet maid is laid upon the bier,
Shuter and I ſhall be chief mourners here.
To her a mawkiſh 〈◊〉 of ſpurious breed,
Who deals in ſ •• t •••• tals will ſucceed!
Poor Ned and I are dead to all intents,
We can as ſoon ſpeak Greek as ſentiments!
Both nervous grown, to keep our ſpirits up,
We now and then take down a hearty cup.
What ſhall we do?—If Comedy forſake us!
They'll turn us out, and no one elſe will take us,
But why can't I be moral?—Let me try—
My heart thus preſſing—fix'd my face and eye—
With a ſententious look, that nothing means,
(Faces are blocks, in ſentimental ſcenes)
Thus I begin—All is not gold that glitters,
Pleaſure ſeems ſweet, but proves a glaſs of bitters.
When ign'rance enters, folly is at hand;
Learning is better far than houſe and land:
Let not your virtue trip, who trips may ſtumble,
And virtue is not virtue, if ſhe tumble.
I give it up—morals won't do for me;
To make you laugh I muſt play tragedy.
One hope remains—hearing the maid was ill,
A doctor comes this night to ſhew his ſkill.
To cheer her heart, and give your muſcles motion,
He in five draughts prepar'd, preſents a potion:
A kind of magic charm—for be aſſur'd,

If y ••
〈◊〉 ſwallow it, the maid is cur'd:
But d •• p ••• te the Doctor, and her caſe is,
If you reject the d • ſe, and make wry faces!
This truth he boaſts, will beaſt it while he lives,
No pois'nous drugs are mix'd in what he gives;
Should he ſucceed, you'll give him his degree;
If not, within he will receive no fee!
The college you, muſt his pretenſions back,
Pronounce him regular, or dub him quack.

div.head: EPILOGUE
div.l: WELL, having ſtoop'd to conquer with ſucceſs,
And gain'd a huſband without aid from dreſs,
Still as a Bar-maid, I could wiſh it too,
As I have conquer'd him to conquer you:
And let me ſay, for all your reſolution,
That pretty Bar-maids have done execution.
Our life is all a play, compos'd to pleaſe,
"We have our exits and our entrances."
The firſt act ſhews the ſimple country maid,
Harmleſs and young, of ev'ry thing aſraid;
Bluſhes when hir'd, and with unmeaning action,
I hopes as how to give you ſatisfaction.
Her ſecond act diſplays a livelier ſcene,—
Th' unbluſhing Bar-maid of a country inn.
Who whiſks about the houſe, at market caters,
Talks loud, coquets the gueſts, and ſcolds the waiters.
Next the ſcene ſhifts to town, and there ſhe ſoars,
The chop houſe toaſt of ogling connoiſſieurs.
On 'Squires and Cits ſhe there diſplays her arts,
And on the gridiron broils her lover's hearts—
And as ſhe ſmiles, her triumphs to compleat,
Even Common Councilmen forget to eat.
The fourth act ſhews her wedded to the 'Squire,
And Madam now begins to hold it higher;
Pretends to taſte, at Operas cries caro,
And quits her Nancy Dawſon, for Che Faro.
Doats upon dancing, and in all her pride,
Swims round the room, the Heinel of Cheapſide:
Ogles and leers with artificial ſkill,
Till having loſt in age the power to kill,
She ſits all night at cards, and ogles at ſpadille.
Such, thro' our lives, the eventful hiſtory—
The fifth and laſt act ſtill remains for me.
The Bar-maid now for your protection prays,
Turns Female Barriſter, and leads for Bayes.

body.head: She Stoops to Conquer: OR, The Miſtakes of a Night.

div.head: ACT I.
div.stage: SCENE, A CHAMBER in an old faſhioned HOUSE. Enter Mrs. HARDCASTLE and Mr. HARDCASTLE.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I Vow, Mr. Hardcaſtle, you're very particular. Is there a creature in the whole country, but ourſelves, that does not take a trip to town now and then, to rub off the ruſt a little? There's the two Miſs Hoggs, and our neighbour, Mrs. Grigſby, go to take a month's poliſhing every winter.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Ay, and bring back vanity and affectation to laſt them the whole year. I wonder why London cannot keep its own fools at home. In my time, the follies of the town crept ſlowly among us, but now they travel faſter than a ſtage-coach. Its fopperies come down, not only as inſide paſſengers, but in the very baſket.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Ay, your times were fine times, indeed; you have been telling us of them for many a long year. Here we live in an old rumbling manſion, that looks for all the world like an inn, but that we never ſee company. Our beſt viſitors are old Mrs. Oddfiſh, the curate's wife, and little Cripplegate, the lame dancing-maſter: And all our entertainment your old ſtories of Prince Eugene and the Duke of Marlborough. I hate ſuch old-faſhioned trumpery.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And I love it. I love every thing that's old: old friends, old times, old manners, old books, old wine; and, I believe, Dorothy, (taking her hand) you'll own I have been pretty fond of an old wife.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Lord, Mr. Hardcaſtle, you're for ever at your Dorothy's and your old wife's. You may be a Darby, but I'll be no Joan, I promiſe you. I'm not ſo old as you'd make me, by more than one good year. Add twenty to twenty, and make money of that.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Let me ſee; twenty added to twenty, makes juſt fifty and ſeven.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: It's falſe, Mr. Hardcaſtle: I was but twenty when I was brought to bed of Tony, that I had by Mr. Lumpkin, my firſt huſband; and he's not come to years of diſcretion yet.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Nor ever will, I dare anſwer for him. Ay, you have taught him finely.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: No matter, Tony Lumpkin has a good fortune. My ſon is not to live by his learning. I don't think a boy wants much learning to ſpend fifteen hundred a year.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Learning, quotha! A mere compoſition of tricks and miſchief.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Humour, my dear: nothing but humour. Come, Mr. Hardcaſtle, you muſt allow the boy a little humour.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I'd ſooner allow him an horſe-pond. If burning the footmens ſhoes, frighting the maids, and worrying the kittens, be humour, he has it. It was but yeſterday he faſtened my wig to the back of my chair, and when I went to make a bow, I popt my bald head in Mrs. Frizzle's face.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And am I to blame? The poor boy was always too ſickly to do any good. A ſchool would be his death. When he comes to be a little ſtronger, who knows what a year or two's Latin may do for him?

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Latin for him! A cat and fiddle. No, no, the ale-houſe and the ſtable are the only ſchools he'll ever go to.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Well, we muſt not ſnub the poor boy now, for I believe we ſhan't have him long among us. Any body that looks in his face may ſee he's conſumptive.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Ay, if growing too fat be one of the ſymptoms.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: He coughs ſometimes.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Yes, when his liquor goes the wrong way.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I'm actually afraid of his lungs.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p:
And truly ſo am I; for he ſometimes whoops like
a ſpeaking trumpet— (Tony hallooing behind the Scenes)—O there he goes—A very conſumptive figure, truly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Tony, where are you going, my charmer? Won't you give papa and I a little of your company, lovee?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: I'm in haſte, mother, I cannot ſtay.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: You ſhan't venture out this raw evening, my dear: You look moſt ſhockingly.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: I can't ſtay, I tell you. The Three Pigeons expects me down every moment. There's ſome fun going forward.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Ay; the ale-houſe, the old place: I thought ſo.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: A low, paltry ſet of fellows.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Not ſo low neither. There's Dick Muggins the exciſeman, Jack Slang the horſe doctor, Little Aminadab that grinds the muſic box, and Tom Twiſt that ſpins the pewter platter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Pray, my dear, diſappoint them for one night at leaſt.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: As for diſappointing them, I ſhould not ſo much mind; but I can't abide to diſappoint myſelf.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: You ſhan't go.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: I will, I tell you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I ſay you ſhan't.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: We'll ſee which is ſtrongeſt, you or I.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Ay, there goes a pair that only ſpoil each other, But is not the whole age in a combination to drive ſenſe and diſcretion out of doors? There's my pretty darling Kate; the faſhions of the times have almoſt infected her too. By living a year or two in town, ſhe is as fond of gauze, and French frippery, as the beſt of them.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Bleſſings on my pretty innocence! Dreſt out as uſual my Kate. Goodneſs! What a quantity of ſuperfluous ſilk has thou got about thee, girl! I could never teach the fools of this age, that the indigent world could be cloathed out of the trimmings of the vain.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: You know our agreement, Sir. You allow me the morning to receive and pay viſits, and to dreſs in my own manner; and in the evening, I put on my houſewife's dreſs to pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Well, remember I inſiſt on the terms of our agreement; and, by the bye, I believe I ſhall have occaſion to try your obedience this very evening.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I proteſt, Sir, I don't comprehend your meaning.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p:
Then, to be plain with you, Kate, I expect the
young gentleman I have choſen to be your huſband from town this very day. I have his father's letter, in which he informs me his ſon is ſet out, and that he intends to follow himſelf ſhortly after.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Indeed! I wiſh I had known ſomething of this before. Bleſs me, how ſhall I behave? It's a thouſand to one I ſhan't like him; our meeting will be ſo formal, and ſo like a thing of buſineſs, that I ſhall find no room for friendſhip or eſteem.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Depend upon it, child, I'll never controul your choice; but Mr. Marlow, whom I have pitched upon, is the ſon of my old friend, Sir Charles Marlow, of whom you have heard me talk ſo often. The young gentleman has been bred a ſcholar, and is deſigned for an employment in the ſervice of his country. I am told he's a man of an excellent underſtanding.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Is he?

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Very generous.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I believe I ſhall like him.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Young and brave.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I'm ſure I ſhall like him.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And very handſome.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: My dear Papa, ſay no more (kiſſing his hand) he's mine, I'll have him.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And to crown all, Kate, he's one of the moſt baſhful and reſerved young fellows in all the world.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Eh! you have frozen me to death again. That word reſerved, has undone all the reſt of his accompliſhments. A reſerved lover, it is ſaid, always makes a ſuſpicious huſband.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: On the contrary, modeſty ſeldom reſides in a breaſt that is not enriched with nobler virtues. It was the very feature in his character that firſt ſtruck me.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: He muſt have more ſtriking features to catch me, I promiſe you. However, if he be ſo young, ſo handſome, and ſo every thing, as you mention, I believe he'll do ſtill. I think I'll have him.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Ay, Kate, but there is ſtill an obſtacle. Its more than an even wager, he may not have you.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: My dear Papa, why will you mortify one ſo?—Well, if he refuſes, inſtead of breaking my heart at his indifference, I'll only break my glaſs for its flattery. Set my cap to ſome newer faſhion, and look out for ſome leſs difficult admirer.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Bravely reſolved! In the mean time I'll go prepare the ſervants for his reception; as we ſeldom ſee company they want as much training as a company of recruits, the firſt day's muſter.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Lud, this news of Papa's, puts me all in a ſlutter. Young, handſome; theſe he put laſt; but I put them foremoſt. Senſible, good-natured; I like all that. But then reſerved, and ſheepiſh, that's much againſt him. Yet can't he be cured of his timidity, by being taught to be proud of his wife? Yes, and can't I—But I vow I'm diſpoſing of the huſband, before I have ſecured the lover.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I'm glad you're come, Neville, my dear. Tell me, Conſtance, how do I look this evening? Is there any thing whimſical about me? Is it one of my well looking days, child? Am I in face to day?

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: Perfectly, my dear. Yet now I look again—bleſs me!—ſure no accident has happened among the canary birds or the gold fiſhes. Has your brother or the cat been meddling? Or has the laſt novel been too moving?

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: No; nothing of all this. I have been threatened—I can ſcarce get it out—I have been threatened with a lover.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: And his name—

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Is Marlow.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: The ſon of Sir Charles Marlow.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: As I live, the moſt intimate friend of Mr. Haſtings, my admirer. They are never aſunder. I believe you muſt have ſeen him when we lived in town.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: He's a very ſingular character, I aſſure you. Among women of reputation and virtue, he is the modeſteſt man alive; but his acquaintance give him a very different character among creatures of another ſtamp: you underſtand me.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p:
An odd character, indeed. I ſhall never be able
to manage him. What ſhall I do? Pſhaw, think no more of him, but truſt to occurrences for ſucceſs. But how goes on your own affair my dear, has my mother been courting you for my brother Tony, as uſual?

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: I have juſt come from one of our agreeable tête a-têtes. She has been ſaying a hundred tender things, and ſetting off her pretty monſter as the very pink of perfection.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And her partiality is ſuch, that ſhe actually thinks him ſo. A fortune like your's is no ſmall temptation. Beſides, as ſhe has the ſole management of it, I'm not ſurprized to ſee her unwilling to let it go out of the family.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: A fortune like mine, which chiefly conſiſts in jewels, is no ſuch mighty temptation. But at any rate if my dear Haſtings be but conſtant, I make no doubt to be too hard for her at laſt. However, I let her ſuppoſe that I am in love with her ſon, and ſhe never once dreams that my affections are fixed upon another.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: My good brother holds out ſtoutly. I could almoſt love him for hating you ſo.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: It is a good natured creature at bottom, and I'm ſure would wiſh to ſee me married to any body but himſelf. But my aunt's bell rings for our afternoon's walk round the improvements. Allons. Courage is neceſſary as our affairs are critical.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Would it were bed time and all were well.

div.stage: SCENE, An Alehouſe Room. Several ſhabby fellows, with Punch and Tobacco. TONY at the head of t • e Table, a little higher than the reſt: A mallet in his hand.

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: Hurrea, hurrea, hurrea, bravo.

sp.speaker: Firſt FELLOW.
sp.p: Now, gentlemen, ſilence for a ſong. The 'Squire is going to knock himſelf down for a ſong.

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: Ay, a ſong, a ſong.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Then I'll ſing you, gentlemen, a ſong I made upon this ale-houſe, the Three Pigeons.

lg.l: Let ſchool-maſters puzzle their brain,
With grammar, and nonſenſe, and learning;
Good liquor, I ſtoutly maintain,
Gives genus a better diſcerning.
Let them brag of their Heatheniſh Gods,
Their Lethes, their Styxes, and Stygians;
Their Quis, and their Quaes, and their Quods,
They're all but a parcel of Pigeons.
When Methodiſt preachers come down,
A preaching that drinking is ſinful,
I'll wager the raſcals a crown,
They always preach beſt with a ſkinful.
But when you come down with your pence,
For a ſlice of their ſcurvy religion,
I'll leave it to all men of ſenſe,
But you my good friend are the pigeon.
Then come, put the jorum about,
And let us be merry and dever,
Our hearts and our liquors are ſtout,
Here's the Three Jolly Pigeons for ever.
Let ſome cry up woodcock or hare,
Your buſtards, your ducks, and your widgeons;
But of all the birds in the air,
Here's a health to the Three Jolly Pigeons.

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: Bravo, bravo.

sp.speaker: Firſt FELLOW.
sp.p: The 'Squire has got ſpunk in him.

sp.speaker: Second FELLOW:
sp.p: I loves to hear him ſing, bekeays he never gives us nothing that's low.

sp.speaker: Third FELLOW.
sp.p: O damn any thing that's low, I cannot bear it.

sp.speaker: Fourth FELLOW.
sp.p: The genteel thing is the genteel thing at any time. If ſo be that a gentleman bees in a concatenation accordingly.

sp.speaker: Third FELLOW.
sp.p: I like the maxum of it, Maſter Muggins. What, tho' I am obligated to dance a bear, a man may be a gentleman for all that. May this be my poiſon if my bear ever dances but to the very genteeleſt of tunes. Water Parted, or the minuet in Ariadne.

sp.speaker: Second FELLOW.
sp.p: What a pity it is the 'Squire is not come to his own. It would be well for all the publicans within ten miles round of him.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Ecod and ſo it would Maſter Slang. I'd then ſhew what it was to keep choice of company.

sp.speaker: Second FELLOW.
sp.p:
O he takes after his own father for that. To be ſure old 'Squire Lumpkin was the fineſt gentleman I ever ſet my eyes on. For winding the ſtreight horn, or beating a thicket for a hare, or a wench he never had his fellow. It was a ſaying in
the place, that he kept the beſt horſes, dogs and girls in the whole county.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Ecod, and when I'm of age I'll be no baſtard I promiſe you. I have been thinking of Bett Bouncer and the miller's grey mare to begin with. But come, my boys, drink about and be merry, for you pay no reckoning. Well Stingo, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: LANDLORD.
sp.p: There be two gentlemen in a poſt-chaiſe at the door. They have loſt their way upo' the foreſt; and they are talking ſomething about Mr. Hardcaſtle.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: As ſure as can be one of them muſt be the gentleman that's coming down to court my ſiſter. Do they ſeem to be Londoners?

sp.speaker: LANDLORD.
sp.p: I believe they may. They look woundily like Frenchmen.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Then deſire them to ſtep this way, and I'll ſet them right in a twinkling. (Exit Landlord.) Gentlemen, as they mayn't be good enough company for you, ſtep down for a moment, and I'll be with you in the ſqueezing of a lemon.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Father-in-law has been calling me whelp, and hound, this half year. Now if I pleaſed, I could be ſo revenged upon the old grumbletonian. But then I'm afraid—afraid of what! I ſhall ſoon be worth fifteen hundred a year, and let him frighten me out of that if he can.

div.stage: Enter LANDLORD, conducting Marlow and Haſtings.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p:
What a tedious uncomfortable day have we had of
it! We were told it was but forty miles acroſs the country, and we have come above threeſcore.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: And all Marlow, from that unaccountable reſerve of yours, that would not let us enquire more frequently on the way.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: I own, Haſtings, I am unwilling to lay myſelf under an obligation to every one I meet; and often, ſtand the chance of an unmannerly anſwer.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: At preſent, however, we are not likely to receive any anſwer.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: No offence, gentlemen. But I'm told you have been enquiring for one Mr. Hardcaſtle, in thoſe parts. Do you know what part of the country you are in?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Not in the leaſt Sir, but ſhould thank you for information.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Nor the way you came?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: No, Sir; but if you can inform us—

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Why, gentlemen, if you know neither the road you are going, nor where you are, nor the road you came, the firſt thing I have to inform you is, that—You have loſt your way.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: We wanted no ghoſt to tell us that.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Pray, gentlemen, may I be ſo bold as to aſk the place from whence you came?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: That's not neceſſary towards directing us where we are to go.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p:
No offence; but queſtion for queſtion is all fair,
you know. Pray, gentlemen, is not this ſame Hardcaſtle a croſs-grain'd, old-faſhion'd, whimſical fellow, with an ugly face; a daughter, and a pretty ſon?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: We have not ſeen the gentleman, but he has the family you mention.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: The daughter, a tall trapeſing, trolloping, talkative maypole—The ſon, a pretty, well-bred, agreeable youth, that every body is fond of.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Our information differs in this. The daughter is ſaid to be well-bred and beautiful; the ſon, an aukward booby, reared up, and ſpoiled at his mother's apron-ſtring.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: He-he-hem—Then, gentlemen, all I have to tell you is, that you won't reach Mr. Hardcaſtle's houſe this night, I believe.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Unfortunate!

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: It's a damn'd long, dark, boggy, dirty, dangerous way. Stingo, tell the gentlemen the way to Mr. Hardcaſtle's; (winking upon the Landlord) Mr. Hardcaſtle's, of Quagmire Marſh, you underſtand me.

sp.speaker: LANDLORD.
sp.p: Maſter Hardcaſtle's! Lock-a-daiſy, my maſters, you're come a deadly deal wrong! When you came to the bottom of the hill, you ſhould have croſs'd down Squaſh-lane.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Croſs down Squaſh-lane!

sp.speaker: LANDLORD.
sp.p: Then you were to keep ſtreight forward, 'till you came to four roads.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Come to where four roads meet!

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Ay; but you muſt be ſure to take only one of them.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: O Sir, you're facetious.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Then keeping to the right, you are to go ſide-ways till you come upon Crack-ſkull common: there you muſt look ſharp for the track of the wheel, and go forward, 'till you come to farmer Murrain's barn. Coming to the farmer's barn, you are to turn to the right, and then to the left, and then to the right about again, till you find out the old mill—

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Zounds, man! we could as ſoon find out the longitude!

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: What's to be done, Marlow?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: This houſe promiſes but a poor reception; though perhaps the Landlord can accommodate us.

sp.speaker: LANDLORD.
sp.p: Alack, maſter, we have but one ſpare bed in the whole houſe.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: And to my knowledge, that's taken up by three lodgers already. (after a pauſe, in which the reſt ſeem diſconcerted) I have hit it. Don't you think, Stingo, our landlady could accommodate the gentlemen by the fire-ſide, with—three chairs and a bolſter?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: I hate ſleeping by the fire-ſide.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: And I deteſt your three chairs and a bolſter.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: You do, do you?—then let me ſee—what—if you go on a mile further, to the Buck's Head; the old Buck's Head on the hill, one of the beſt inns in the whole county?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: O ho! ſo we have eſcaped an adventure for this night, however.

sp.speaker: LANDLORD.
sp.p: Sure, you ben't ſending them to your father's as an inn, be you?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Mum, you fool you. Let them find that out. (to them) You have only to keep on ſtreight forward, till you come to a large old houſe by the road ſide. You'll ſee a pair of large horns over the door. That's the ſign. Drive up the yard, and call ſtoutly about you.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Sir, we are obliged to you. The ſervants can't miſs the way?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: No, no: But I tell you though, the landlord is rich, and going to leave off buſineſs; ſo he wants to be thought a Gentleman, ſaving your preſence, he! he! he! He'll be for giving you his company, and ecod if you mind him, he'll perſuade you that his mother was an alderman, and his aunt a juſtice of peace.

sp.speaker: LANDLORD.
sp.p: A troubleſome old blade to be ſure; but a keeps as good wines and beds as any in the whole country.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Well, if he ſupplies us with theſe, we ſhall want no further connexion. We are to turn to the right, did you ſay?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: No, no; ſtreight forward. I'll juſt ſtep myſelf, and ſhew you a piece of the way. (to the landlord) Mum.

sp.speaker: LANDLORD.
sp.p: Ah, bleſs your heart, for a ſweet, pleaſant—damn'd miſchievous ſon of a whore.

div.head: ACT II.
div.stage: Enter HARDCASTLE, followed by three or four aukward Servants.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: WELL, I hope you're perfect in the table exerciſe I have been teaching you theſe three days. You all know your poſts and your places, and can ſhew that you have been uſed to good company, without ever ſtirring from home.

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: Ay, ay,

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: When company comes, you are not to pop out and ſtare, and then run in again, like frighted rabbits in a warren.

sp.speaker: OMNES.
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: You, Diggory, whom I have taken from the barn, are to make a ſhew at the ſide-table; and you, Roger, whom I have advanced from the plough, are to place yourſelf behind my chair. But you're not to ſtand ſo, with your hands in your pockets. Take your hands from your pockets, Roger; and from your head, you blockhead you. See how Diggory carries his hands. They're a little too ſtiff, indeed, but that's no great matter.

sp.speaker: DIGGORY.
sp.p: Ay, mind how I hold them. I learned to hold my hands this way, when I was upon drill for the militia. And ſo being upon drill—

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p:
You muſt not be ſo talkative, Diggory. You muſt be all attention to the gueſts. You muſt hear us talk,
and not think of talking; you muſt ſee us drink, and not think of drinking; you muſt ſee us eat, and not think of eating.

sp.speaker: DIGGORY.
sp.p: By the laws, your worſhip, that's parfectly unpoſſible. Whenever Diggory ſees yeating going forward, ecod he's always wiſhing for a mouthful himſelf.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Blockhead! Is not a belly-full in the kitchen as good as a belly-full in the parlour? Stay your ſtomach with that reflection.

sp.speaker: DIGGORY.
sp.p: Ecod I thank your worſhip, I'll make a ſhift to ſtay my ſtomach with a ſlice of cold beef in the pantry.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Diggory, you are too talkative. Then if I happen to ſay a good thing, or tell a good ſtory at table, you muſt not all burſt out a-laughing, as if you made part of the company.

sp.speaker: DIGGORY.
sp.p: Then ecod your worſhip muſt not tell the ſtory of Ould Grouſe in the gun-room: I can't help laughing at that—he! he! he!—for the ſoul of me. We have laughed at that theſe twenty years—ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! The ſtory is a good one. Well, honeſt Diggory, you may laugh at that—but ſtill remember to be attentive. Suppoſe one of the company ſhould call for a glaſs of wine, how will you behave? A glaſs of wine, Sir, if you pleaſe (to Diggory)—Eh, why don't you move?

sp.speaker: DIGGORY.
sp.p: Ecod, your worſhip, I never have courage till I ſee the eatables and drinkables brought upo' the table, and then I'm as bauld as a lion.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: What, will no body move?

sp.speaker: FIRST SERVANT.
sp.p: I'm not to leave this pleace.

sp.speaker: SECOND SERVANT.
sp.p: I'm ſure it's no pleace of mine.

sp.speaker: THIRD SERVANT.
sp.p: Nor mine, for ſartain.

sp.speaker: DIGGORY.
sp.p: Wauns, and I'm ſure it canna be mine.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: You numbſkulls! and ſo while, like your betters, you are quarrelling for places, the gueſts muſt be ſtarved. O you dunces! I find I muſt begin all over again.—But don't I hear a coach drive into the yard? To your poſts, you blockheads. I'll go in the mean time and give my old friend's ſon a hearty reception at the gate.

sp.speaker: DIGGORY.
sp.p: By the elevens, my pleace is gone quite out of my head.

sp.speaker: ROGER.
sp.p: I know that my pleace is to be every where.

sp.speaker: FIRST SERVANT.
sp.p: Where the devil is mine?

sp.speaker: SECOND SERVANT.
sp.p: My pleace is to be no where at all; and ſo Ize go about my buſineſs.

div.stage: [Exeunt Servants, running about as if frighted, different ways.
Enter SERVANT with Candles, ſhewing in MARLOW and HASTINGS.

sp.speaker: SERVANT.
sp.p: Welcome, gentlemen, very welcome. This way.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: After the diſappointments of the day, welcome once more, Charles, to the comforts of a clean room and a good fire. Upon my word, a very well-looking houſe; antique, but creditable.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: The uſual fate of a large manſion. Having firſt ruined the maſter by good houſekeeping, it at laſt comes to levy contributions as an inn.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: As you ſay, we paſſengers are to be taxed to pay all theſe fineries. I have often ſeen a good ſideboard, or a marble chimney-piece, tho' not actually put in the bill, enflame a reckoning confoundedly.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Travellers, George, muſt pay in all places. The only difference is, that in good inns, you pay dearly for luxuries; in bad inns, you are fleeced and ſtarved.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: You have lived pretty much among them. In truth, I have been often ſurprized, that you who have ſeen ſo much of the world, with your natural good ſenſe, and your many opportunities, could never yet acquire a requiſite ſhare of aſſurance.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: The Engliſhman's malady. But tell me, George, where could I have learned that aſſurance you talk of? My life has been chiefly ſpent in a college, or an inn, in ſecluſion from that lovely part of the creation that chiefly teach men confidence. I don't know that I was ever familiarly acquainted with a ſingle modeſt woman—except my mother—But among females of another claſs you know—

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Ay, among them you are impudent enough of all conſcience.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: They are of us you know.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: But in the company of women of reputation I never ſaw ſuch an ideot, ſuch a trembler; you look for all the world as if you wanted an opportunity of ſtealing out of the room.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p:
Why man that's becauſe I do want to ſteal out of the room. Faith, I have often formed
a reſolution to break the ice, and rattle away at any rate. But I don't know how, a ſingle glance from a pair of fine eyes has totally overſet my reſolution. An impudent fellow may counterfeit modeſty, but I'll be hanged if a modeſt man can ever counterfeit impudence.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: If you could but ſay half the fine things to them that I have heard you laviſh upon the bar-maid of an inn, or even a college bed maker—

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Why, George, I can't ſay fine things to them, They freeze, they petrify me. They may talk of a comet, or a burning mountain, or ſome ſuch bagatelle. But to me, a modeſt woman, dreſt out in all her finery, is the moſt tremendous object of the whole creation.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! At this rate, man, how can you ever expect to marry!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Never, unleſs as among kings and princes, my bride were to be courted by proxy. If, indeed, like an Eaſtern bridegroom, one were to be introduced to a wife he never ſaw before, it might be endured. But to go through all the terrors of a formal courtſhip, together with the epiſode of aunts, grandmothers and couſins, and at laſt to blurt out the broad ſtaring queſtion, of, madam will you marry me? No, no, that's ſtrain much above me I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: I pity you. But how do you intend behaving to the lady you are come down to viſit at the requeſt of your father?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p:
As I behave to all other ladies. Bow very low. Anſwer yes, or no, to all her demands—But for
the reſt, I don't think I ſhall venture to look in her face, till I ſee my father's again.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: I'm ſurprized that one who is ſo warm a friend can be ſo cool a lover.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: To be explicit, my dear Haſtings, my chief inducement down was to be inſtrumental in forwarding your happineſs, not my own. Miſs Neville loves you, the family don't know you, as my friend you are ſure of a reception, and let honour do the reſt.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: My dear Marlow! But I'll ſuppreſs the emotion. Were I a wretch, meanly ſeeking to carry off a fortune, you ſhould be the laſt man in the world I would apply to for aſſiſtance. But Miſs Neville's perſon is all I aſk, and that is mine, both from her deceaſed father's conſent, and her own inclination.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Happy man! You have talents and art to captivate any woman. I'm doom'd to adore the ſex, and yet to converſe with the only part of it I deſpiſe. This ſtammer in my addreſs, and this aukward prepoſſeſſing viſage of mine, can never permit me to ſoar above the reach of a milliner's 'prentice, or one of the dutcheſſes of Drury-lane. Pſhaw! this fellow here to interrupt us.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Gentlemen, once more you are heartily welcome. Which is Mr. Marlow? Sir, you're heartily welcome. It's not my way, you ſee, to receive my friends with my back to the fire. I like to give them a hearty reception in the old ſtile at my gate. I like to ſee their horſes and trunks taken care of.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p:
He has got our names from the ſervants already.
(To Him) We approve your caution and hoſpitality, Sir. (To Haſtings) I have been thinking, George, of changing our travelling dreſſes in the morning. I am grown confoundedly aſhamed of mine.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I beg, Mr. Marlow, you'll uſe no ceremony in this houſe.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: I fancy, George, you're right: the firſt blow is half the battle. I intend opening the campaign with the white and gold.

sp.speaker: Mr. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Mr. Marlow—Mr. Haſtings—gentlemen—pray be under no conſtraint in this houſe. This is Liberty-hall, gentlemen. You may do juſt as you pleaſe here.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Yet, George, if we open the campaign too fiercely at firſt, we may want ammunition before it is over. I think to reſerve the embroidery to ſecure a retreat.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Your talking of a retreat, Mr. Marlow, puts me in mind of the Duke of Marlborough, when we went to beſiege Denain. He firſt ſummoned the garriſon.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Don't you think the ventre dor waiſtcoat will do with the plain brown?

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: He firſt ſummoned the garriſon, which might conſiſt of about five thouſand men—

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: I think not: Brown and yellow mix but very poorly.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I ſay, gentlemen, as I was telling you, he ſummoned the garriſon, which might conſiſt of about five thouſand men—

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: The girls like finery.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Which might conſiſt of about five thouſand men, well appointed with ſtores, ammunition, and other implements of war. Now, ſays the Duke of Marlborough, to George Brooks, that ſtood next to him—You muſt have heard of George Brooks; I'll pawn my Dukedom, ſays he, but I take that garriſon without ſpilling a drop of blood. So—

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: What, my good friend, if you gave us a glaſs of punch in the mean time, it would help us to carry on the ſiege with vigour.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Punch, Sir! (aſide) This is the moſt unaccountable kind of modeſty I ever met with.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, Punch. A glaſs of warm punch, after our journey, will be comfortable. This is Liberty-Hall, you know.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Here's Cup, Sir.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: So this fellow, in his Liberty-hall, will only let us have juſt what he pleaſes.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I hope you'll find it to your mind. I have prepared it with my own hands, and I believe you'll own the ingredients are tolerable. Will you, be ſo good as to pledge me, Sir? Here, Mr. Marlow, here is to our better acquaintance.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: A very impudent fellow this! but he's a character, and I'll humour him a little. Sir, my ſervice to you.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: I ſee this fellow wants to give us his company, and forgets that he's an innkeeper, before he has learned to be a gentleman.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: From the excellence of your cup, my old friend, I ſuppoſe you have a good deal of buſineſs in this part of the country. Warm work, now and then, at elections, I ſuppoſe.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: No, Sir, I have long given that work over. Since our betters have hit upon the expedient of electing each other, there's no buſineſs for us that ſell ale.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: So, then you have no turn for politics I find.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Not in the leaſt. There was a time, indeed, I fretted myſelf about the miſtakes of government, like other people; but finding myſelf every day grow more angry, and the government growing no better, I left it to mend itſelf. Since that, I no more trouble my head about Heyder Ally, or Ally Cawn, than about Ally Croaker. Sir, my ſervice to you.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: So that with eating above ſtairs, and drinking below, with receiving your friends within, and amuſing them without, you lead a good pleaſant buſtling life of it.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I do ſtir about a great deal, that's certain. Half the differences of the pariſh are adjuſted in this very parlour.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: And you have an argument in your cup, old gentleman, better than any in Weſtminſter-hall.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTE.
sp.p: Ay, young gentleman, that, and a little philoſophy.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Well, this is the firſt time I ever heard of an innkeeper's philoſophy.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: So then, like an experienced general, you attack them on every quarter. If you find their reaſon manageable, you attack it with your philoſophy; if you find they have no reaſon, you attack them with this. Here's your health, my philoſopher.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Good, very good, thank you; ha, ha. Your Generalſhip puts me in mind of Prince Eugene, when he fought the Turks at the battle of Belgrade. You ſhall hear.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Inſtead of the battle of Belgrade. I believe it's almoſt time to talk about ſupper. What has your philoſophy got in the houſe for fupper?

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: For Supper, Sir! (aſide) Was ever ſuch a requeſt to a man in his own houſe!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, ſupper Sir; I begin to feel an appetite. I ſhall make deviliſh work to-night in the larder, I promiſe you.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Such a brazen dog ſure never my eyes beheld. (to him) Why really, Sir, as for ſupper I can't well tell. My Dorothy, and the cook maid, ſettle theſe things between them. I leave theſe kind of things entirely to them.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: You do, do you?

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Entirely. By-the-bye, I believe they are in actual conſultation upon what's for ſupper this moment in the kitchen.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p:
Then I beg they'll admit me as one of their privy
council. It's a way I have got. When I travel, I always chuſe to regulate my own ſupper. Let the cook be called. No offence I hope, Sir.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: O no, Sir, none in the leaſt; yet I don't know how: our Bridget, the cook maid, is not very communicative upon theſe occaſions. Should we ſend for her, ſhe might ſcold us all out of the houſe.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Let's ſee your liſt of the larder then. I aſk it as a favour. I always match my appetite to my bill of fare.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.stage: (To Hardcaſtle, who looks at them with ſurprize)
sp.p: Sir, he's very right, and it's my way too.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Sir, you have a right to command here. Here, Roger, bring us the bill of fare for to night's ſupper. I believe it's drawn out. Your manner, Mr. Haſtings, puts me in mind of my uncle, Colonel Wallop. It was a ſaying of his, that no man was ſure of his ſupper till he had eaten it.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: All upon the high ropes! His uncle a Colonel! We ſhall ſoon hear of his mother being a juſtice of peace. But let's hear the bill of fare.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: What's here? For the firſt courſe; for the ſecond courſe; for the deſert. The devil, Sir, do you think we have brought down the whole Joiners Company, or the Corporation of Bedford, to eat up ſuch a ſupper? Two or three little things, clean and comfortable, will do.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: But, let's hear it.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: For the firſt courſe at the top, a pig, and pruin ſauce.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Damn your pig, I ſay.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: And damn your pruin ſauce, ſay I.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And yet, gentlemen, to men that are hungry, pig, with pruin ſauce, is very good eating.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: At the bottom, a calve's tongue and brains.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Let your brains be knock'd out, my good Sir; I don't like them.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Or you may clap them on a plate by themſelves. I do.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Their impudence confounds me. (to them) Gentlemen, you are my gueſts, make what alterations you pleaſe. Is there any thing elſe you wiſh to retrench or alter, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Item. A pork pie, a boiled rabbet and ſaufages, a florentine, a ſhaking pudding, and a diſh of tiff—taff—taffety cream!

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Confound your made diſhes, I ſhall be as much at a loſs in this houſe as at a green and yellow dinner at the French ambaſſador's table. I'm for plain eating.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I'm ſorry, gentlemen, that I have nothing you like, but if there be any thing you have a particular fancy to—

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Why, really, Sir, your bill of fare is ſo exquiſite, that any one part of it is full as good as another. Send us what you pleaſe. So much for ſupper. And now to ſee that our beds are air'd, and properly taken care of.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I entreat you'll leave all that to me. You ſhall not ſtir a ſtep.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Leave that to you! I proteſt, Sir, you muſt excuſe me, I always look to theſe things myſelf.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I muſt inſiſt, Sir, you'll make yourſelf eaſy on that head.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: You ſee I'm reſolved on it. (aſide) A very troubleſome fellow this, as ever I met with.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I'm reſolved at leaſt to attend you. (aſide) This may be modern modeſty, but I never ſaw any thing look ſo like old-faſhioned impudence.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: So I find this fellow's civilities begin to grow troubleſome. But who can be angry at thoſe aſſiduities which are meant to pleaſe him? Ha! what do I ſee? Miſs Neville, by all that's happy!

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: My dear Haſtings! To what unexpected good fortune? to what accident am I to aſcribe this happy meeting?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Rather let me aſk the ſame queſtion, as I could never have hoped to meet my deareſt Conſtance at an inn.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: An inn! ſure you miſtake! my aunt, my guardian, lives here. What could induce you to think this houſe an inn?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: My friend Mr. Marlow, with whom I came down, and I, have been ſent here as to an inn, I aſſure you. A young fellow whom we accidentally met at a houſe hard by directed us hither.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: Certainly it muſt be one of my hopeful couſin's tricks, of whom you have heard me talk ſo often, ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: He whom your aunt intends for you? He of whom I have ſuch juſt apprehenſions?

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: You have nothing to fear from him, I aſſure you. You'd adore him if you knew how heartily he deſpiſes me. My aunt knows it too, and has undertaken to court me for him, and actually begins to think ſhe has made a conqueſt.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Thou dear diſſembler! You muſt know, my Conſtance, I have juſt ſeized this happy opportunity of my friend's viſit here to get admittance into the family. The horſes that carried us down are now fatigued with their journey, but they'll ſoon be refreſhed; and then if my deareſt girl will truſt in her faithful Haſtings, we ſhall ſoon be landed in France, where even among ſlaves the laws of marriage are reſpected.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: I have often told you, that though ready to obey you, I yet ſhould leave my little fortune behind with reluctance. The greateſt part of it was left me by my uncle, the India Director, and chiefly conſiſts in jewels. I have been for ſome time perſuading my aunt to let me wear them. I fancy I'm very near ſucceeding. The inſtant they are put into my poſſeſſion you ſhall find me ready to make them and myſelf yours.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Periſh the baubles! Your perſon is all I deſire. In the meantime, my friend Marlow muſt not be let into his miſtake. I know the ſtrange reſerve of his temper is ſuch, that if abruptly informed of it, he would inſtantly quit the houſe before our plan was ripe for execution.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: But how ſhall we keep him in the deception? Miſs Hardcaſtle is juſt returned from walking; what if we ſtill continue to deceive him?—This, this way—

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: The aſſiduities of theſe good people teize me beyond bearing. My hoſt ſeems to think it ill manners to leave me alone, and ſo he claps not only himſelf but his old-faſhioned wife on my back. They talk of coming to ſup with us too; and then, I ſuppoſe, we are to run the gauntlet thro' all the reſt of the family.—What have we got here!—

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: My dear Charles! Let me congratulate you!—The moſt fortunate accident!—Who do you think is juſt alighted?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Cannot gueſs.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Our miſtreſſes boy, Miſs Hardcaſtle and Miſs Neville. Give me leave to introduce Miſs Conſtance Neville to your acquaintance. Happening to dine in the neighbourhood, they called, on their return to take freſh horſes, here. Miſs Hardcaſtle has juſt ſtept into the next room, and will be back in an inſtant. Wasn't it lucky? eh!

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: I have juſt been mortified enough of all conſcience, and here comes ſomething to complete my embarraſſment.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Well! but wasn't it the moſt fortunate thing in the world?

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p:
Oh! yes. Very fortunate—a moſt joyful encounter—But our dreſſes, George, you know,
are in diſorder—What if we ſhould poſtpone the happineſs 'till to-morrow?—To-morrow at her own houſe—It will be every bit as convenient—And rather more reſpectful—To-morrow let it be.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: By no means, Sir. Your ceremony will diſpleaſe her. The diſorder of your dreſs will ſhew the ardour of your impatience. Beſides, ſhe knows you are in the houſe, and will permit you to ſee her.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: O! the devil! how ſhall I ſupport it? Hem! hem! Haſtings, you muſt not go. You are to aſſiſt me, you know. I ſhall be confoundedly ridiculous. Yet, hang it! I'll take courage. Hem!

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Pſhaw man! it's but the firſt plunge, and all's over. She's but a woman, you know.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: And of all women, ſhe that I dread moſt to encounter!
Enter Miſs HARDCASTLE as returned from walking, a Bonnet, &c.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS,
sp.p: Miſs Hardcaſtle, Mr. Marlow, I'm proud of bringing two perſons of ſuch merit together, that only want to know, to eſteem each other.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE
sp.p: Now, for meeting my modeſt gentleman with a demure face, and quite in his own manner. (After a pauſe, in which he appears very uneaſy and diſconcerted.) I'm glad of your ſafe arrival, Sir—I'm told you had ſome accidents by the way.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Only a few madam. Yes, we had ſome. Yes, Madam, a good many accidents, but ſhould be ſorry—Madam—or rather glad of any accidents—that are ſo agreeably concluded. Hem!

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: You never ſpoke better in your whole life. Keep it up, and I'll inſure you the victory.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I'm afraid you flatter, Sir. You that have ſeen ſo much of the fineſt company can find little entertainment in an obſcure corner of the country.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: I have lived, indeed, in the world, Madam; but I have kept very little company. I have been but an obſerver upon life, Madam, while others were enjoying it.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: But that, I am told, is the way to enjoy it at laſt.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Cicero never ſpoke better. Once more, and you are confirm'd in aſſurance for ever.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Hem! Stand by me then, and when I'm down, throw in a word or two to ſet me up again.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: An obſerver, like you, upon life, were, I fear, diſagreeably employed, ſince you muſt have had much more to cenſure than to approve.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Pardon me, Madam. I was always willing to be amuſed. The folly of moſt people is rather an object of mirth than uneaſineſs.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Bravo, Bravo. Never ſpoke ſo well in your whole life. Well! Miſs Hardcaſtle, I ſee that you and Mr. Marlow are going to be very good company. I believe our being here will but embarraſs the interview.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Not in the leaſt, Mr. Haſtings. We like your company of all things. (To him.) Zounds! George, ſure you won't go? How can you leave us?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Our preſence will but ſpoil converſation, ſo we'll retire to the next room. (To him) You don't conſider, man, that we are to manage a little tête-à-tête of our own.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: But you have not been wholly an obſerver, I preſume, Sir: The ladies I ſhould hope have employed ſome part of your addreſſes.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Pardon me, Madam, I—I—I—as yet have ſtudied—only—to—deſerve them.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And that ſome ſay is the very worſt way to obtain them.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Perhaps ſo, madam. But I love to converſe only with the more grave and ſenſible part of the ſex.—But I'm afraid I grow tireſome.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p:
Not at all, Sir; there is nothing I like ſo much as grave converſation myſelf; I could hear it for ever. Indeed I have often been ſurprized how a
man of ſentiment could ever admire thoſe light airy pleaſures, where nothing reaches the heart.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: It's—a diſeaſe—of the mind, madam. In the variety of taſtes there muſt be ſome who wanting a reliſh—for—um—a—um.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I underſtand you, Sir. There muſt be ſome, who wanting a reliſh for refined pleaſures, pretend to deſpiſe what they are incapable of taſting.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: My meaning, madam, but infinitely better expreſſed. And I can't help obſerving—a—

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Who could ever ſuppoſe this fellow impudent upon ſome occaſions. (To him) You were going to obſerve, Sir—

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: I was obſerving, madam—I proteſt, madam, I forget what I was going to obſerve.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I vow and ſo do I. (To him) You were obſerving, Sir, that in this age of hypocriſy ſomething about hypocriſy, Sir.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Yes, madam. In this age of hypocriſy there are few who upon ſtrict enquiry do not—a—a—a—

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I underſtand you perfectly, Sir.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Egad! and that's more than I do myſelf.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p:
You mean that in this hypocritical age there are few that do not condemn in public what they practiſe
in private, and think they pay every debt to virtue when they praiſe it.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: True, madam; thoſe who have moſt virtue in their mouths, have leaſt of it in their boſoms. But I'm ſure I tire you, madam.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Not in the leaſt, Sir; there's ſomething ſo agreeable and ſpirited in your manner, ſuch life and force—pray, Sir, go on.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Yes, madam. I was ſaying—that there are ſome occaſions—when a total want of courage, madam, deſtroys all the—and puts us—upon a—a—a—

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I agree with you entirely, a want of courage upon ſome occaſions aſſumes the appearance of ignorance, and betrays us when we moſt want to excel. I beg you'll proceed.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Yes, madam. Morally ſpeaking, madam—But I ſee Miſs Neville expecting us in the next room. I would not intrude for the world.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I proteſt, Sir, I never was more agreeably entertained in all my life. Pray go on.

sp.speaker: MARLOW.
sp.p: Yes, madam. I was—But ſhe beckons us to join her. Madam, ſhall I do myſelf the honour to attend you?

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Well then, I'll follow.

sp.speaker: MARLOW
sp.p: This pretty ſmooth dialogue has done for me.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! Was there ever ſuch a ſober ſentimental interview? I'm certain he ſcarce look'd in my face the whole time. Yet the fellow, but for his unaccountable baſhfulneſs, is pretty well too. He has good ſenſe, but then ſo buried in his fears, that it fatigues one more than ignorance. If I could teach him a little confidence, it would be doing ſomebody that I know of a piece of ſervice. But who is that ſomebody?—that, faith, is a queſtion I can ſcarce anſwer.

div.stage: Enter TONY and Miſs NEVILLE, followed by Mrs. HARDCASTLE and HASTINGS.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: What do you follow me for, couſin Con? I wonder you're not aſhamed to be ſo very engaging.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: I hope, couſin, one may ſpeak to one's own relations, and not be to blame.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Ay, but I know what ſort of a relation you want to make me though; but it won't do. I tell you, couſin Con, it won't do, ſo I beg you'll keep your diſtance, I want no nearer relationſhip.

div.stage: [She follows coqueting him to the back ſcene.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Well! I vow, Mr. Haſtings, you are very entertaining. There's nothing in the world I love to talk of ſo much as London, and the faſhions, though I was never there myſelf.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Never there! You amaze me! From your air and manner, I concluded you had been bred all your life either at Ranelagh, St. James's, or Tower Wharf.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: O! Sir, you're only pleaſed to ſay ſo. We Country perſons can have no manner at all. I'm in love with the town, and that ſerves to raiſe me above ſome of our neighbouring ruſtics; but who can have a manner, that has never ſeen the Pantheon, the Grotto Gardens, the Borough, and ſuch places where the Nobility chiefly reſort? All I can do, is to enjoy London at ſecond-hand. I take care to know every tête-à-tête from the Scandalous Magazine, and have all the faſhions, as they come out, in a letter from the two Miſs Rickets of Crookedlane. Pray how do you like this head, Mr. Haſtings?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Extremely elegant and degagée, upon my word, Madam. Your Friſeur is a Frenchman, I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I proteſt I dreſſed it myſelf from a print in the Ladies Memorandum-book for the laſt year.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Indeed. Such a head in a ſide-box, at the Playhouſe, would draw as many gazers as my Lady May'reſs at a City Ball.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I vow, ſince inoculation began, there is no ſuch thing to be ſeen as a plain woman; ſo one muſt dreſs a little particular or one may eſcape in the crowd.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: But that can never be your caſe, Madam, in any dreſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Yet, what ſignifies my dreſſing when I have ſuch a piece of antiquity by my ſide as Mr. Hardcaſtle: all I can ſay will never argue down a ſingle button from his cloaths. I have often wanted him to throw off his great flaxen wig, and where he was bald, to plaiſter it over like my Lord Pately, with powder.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: You are right, Madam; for, as among the ladies, there are none ugly, ſo among the men there are none old.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: But what do you think his anſwer was? Why, with his uſual Gothic vivacity, he ſaid I only wanted him to throw off his wig to convert it into a tête for my own wearing.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Intolerable! At your age you may wear what you pleaſe, and it muſt become you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Pray, Mr. Haſtings, what do you take to be the moſt faſhionable age about town?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Some time ago, forty was all the mode; but I'm told the ladies intend to bring up fifty for the enſuing winter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Seriouſly. Then I ſhall be too young for the faſhion.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: No lady begins now to put on jewels 'till ſhe's paſt forty. For inſtance, Miſs there, in a polite circle, would be conſidered as a child, as a mere maker of ſamplers.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And yet Mrs. Niece thinks herſelf as much a woman, and is as fond of jewels as the oldeſt of us all.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Your niece, is ſhe? And that young gentleman, a brother of yours, I ſhould preſume?

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: My ſon, Sir. They are contracted to each other. Obſerve their little ſports. They fall in and out ten times a day, as if they were man and wife already. (To them.) Well Tony, child, what ſoft things are you ſaying to your couſin Conſtance this evening?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: I have been ſaying no ſoft things; but that it's very hard to be followed about ſo. Ecod! I've not a place in the houſe now that's left to myſelf but the ſtable.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Never mind him, Con. my dear. He's in another ſtory behind your back.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: There's ſomething generous in my couſin's manner. He falls out before faces to be forgiven in private.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: That's a damned confounded—crack.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Ah! he's a ſly one. Don't you think they're like each other about the mouth, Mr. Haſtings? The Blenkinſop mouth to a T. They're of a ſize too. Back to back, my pretties, that Mr. Haſtings may ſee you. Come Tony.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: You had as good not make me, I tell you.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: O lud! he has almoſt cracked my head.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: O the monſter! For ſhame, Tony. You a man, and behave ſo!

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: If I'm a man, let me have my fortin. Ecod! I'll not be made a fool of no longer.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Is this, ungrateful boy, all that I'm to get for the pains I have taken in your education? I that have rock'd you in your cradle, and fed that pretty mouth with a ſpoon! Did not I work that waiſtcoat to make you genteel? Did not I preſcribe for you every day, and weep while the receipt was operating?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Ecod! you had reaſon to weep, for you have been doſing me ever ſince I was born. I have gone through every receipt in the complete huſwife ten times over; and you have thoughts of courſing me through Quincy next ſpring. But, Ecod! I tell you, I'll not be made a fool of no longer.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Wasn't it all for your good, viper? Wasn't it all for your good?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: I wiſh you'd let me and my good alone then. Snubbing this way when I'm in ſpirits. If I'm to have any good, let it come of itſelf; not to keep dinging it, dinging it into one ſo.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: That's falſe; I never ſee you when you're in ſpirits. No, Tony, you then go to the alehouſe or kennel. I'm never to be delighted with your agreeable, wild notes, unfeeling monſter!

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Ecod! Mamma, your own notes are the wildeſt of the two.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Was ever the like? But I ſee he wants to break my heart, I ſee he does.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Dear Madam, permit me to lecture the young gentleman a little. I'm certain I can perſuade him to his duty.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Well! I muſt retire. Come, Conſtance, my love. You ſee Mr. Haſtings, the wretchedneſs of my ſituation: Was ever poor woman ſo plagued with a dear, ſweet, pretty, provoking, undutiful boy.

sp.speaker: TONY,
sp.p:
There was a young man riding by, and fain would have his will. Rang do didlo dee. Don't mind her.
Let her cry. It's the comfort of her heart. I have ſeen her and ſiſter cry over a book for an hour together, and they ſaid, they liked the book the better the more it made them cry.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Then you're no friend to the ladies, I find, my pretty young gentleman?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: That's as I find 'um.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Not to her of your mother's chuſing, I dare anſwer? And yet ſhe appears to me a pretty well-tempered girl.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: That's becauſe you don't know her as well as I. Ecod! I know every inch about her; and there's not a more bitter cantanckerous toad in all Chriſtendom.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Pretty encouragement this for a lover!

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: I have ſeen her ſince the height of that. She has as many tricks as a hare in a thicket, or a colt the firſt day's breaking.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: To me ſhe appears ſenſible and ſilent!

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Ay, before company. But when ſhe's with her play-mates ſhe's as loud as a hog in a gate.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: But there is a meek modeſty about her that charms me.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Yes, but curb her never ſo little, ſhe kicks up, and you're flung in a ditch.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Well, but you muſt allow her a little beauty.—Yes, you muſt allow her ſome beauty.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Bandbox! She's all a made up thing, mun. Ah! could you but ſee Bet Bouncer of theſe parts, you might then talk of beauty. Ecod, ſhe has two eyes as black as ſloes, and cheeks as broad and red as a pulpit cuſhion. She'd make two of ſhe.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Well, what ſay you to a friend that would take this bitter bargain off your hands?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Anon.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Would you thank him that would take Miſs Neville and leave you to happineſs and your dear Betſy?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Ay; but where is there ſuch a friend, for who would take her?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: I am he. If you but aſſiſt me, I'll engage to whip her off to France, and you ſhall never hear more of her.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Aſſiſt you! Ecod I will, to the laſt drop of my blood. I'll clap a pair of horſes to your chaiſe that ſhall trundle you off in a twinkling, and may be get you a part of her fortin beſide, in jewels, that you little dream of.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: My dear ſquire, this looks like a lad of ſpirit.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Come along then, and you ſhall ſee more of my ſpirit before you have done with me (ſinging). We are the boys that fears no noiſe where the thundering cannons roar.

div.head: ACT III.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: WHAT could my old friend Sir Charles mean by recommending his ſon as the modeſteſt young man in town? To me he appears the moſt impudent piece of braſs that ever ſpoke with a tongue. He has taken poſſeſſion of the eaſy chair by the fire-ſide already. He took off his boots in the parlour, and deſired me to ſee them taken care of. I'm deſirous to know how his impudence affects my daughter.—She will certainly be ſhocked at it.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Well, my Kate, I ſee you have changed your dreſs as I bid you; and yet, I believe, there was no great occaſion.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I find ſuch a pleaſure, Sir, in obeying your commands, that I take care to obſerve them without ever debating their propriety.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And yet, Kate, I ſometimes give you ſome cauſe, particularly when I recommended my modeſt gentleman to you as a lover to-day.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: You taught me to expect ſomething extraordinary, and I find the original exceeds the deſcription.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I was never ſo ſurprized in my life! He has quite confounded all my faculties!

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I never ſaw any thing like it: And a man of the world too!

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Ay, he learned it all abroad,—what a fool was I, to think a young man could learn modeſty by travelling. He might as ſoon learn wit at a maſquerade.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: It ſeems all natural to him.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: A good deal aſſiſted by bad company and a French dancing-maſter.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Sure you miſtake, papa! a French dancing-maſter could never have taught him that timid look,—that aukward addreſs,—that baſhful manner—

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Whoſe look? whoſe manner? child!

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Mr. Marlow's: his meanvaiſe Loute, his timidity ſtruck me at the firſt ſight.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Then your firſt ſight deceived you; for I think him one of the moſt brazen firſt ſights that ever aſtoniſhed my ſenſes.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Sure, Sir, you rally! I never ſaw any one ſo modeſt.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And can you be ſerious! I never ſaw ſuch a bouncing ſwaggering puppy ſince I was born. Bully Dawſon was but a fool to him.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Surprizing! He met me with a reſpectful bow, a ſtammering voice, and a look fixed on the ground.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: He met me with a loud voice, a lordly air, and a familiarity that made my blood freeze again.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: He treated me with diffidence and reſpect; cenſured the manners of the age; admired the prudence of girls that never laughed; tired me with apologies for being tireſome; then left the room with a bow, and, madam, I would not for the world detain you.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: He ſpoke to me as if he knew me all his life before. Aſked twenty queſtions, and never waited for an anſwer. Interrupted my beſt remarks with ſome ſilly pun, and when I was in my beſt ſtory of the Duke of Marlborough and Prince Eugene, he aſked if I had not a good hand at making punch. Yes, Kate, he aſk'd your father if he was a maker of punch!

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: One of us muſt certainly be miſtaken.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: If he be what he has ſhewn himſelf, I'm determined he ſhall never have my conſent.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And if he be the ſullen thing I take him, he ſhall never have mine.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: In one thing then we are agreed—to reject him.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Yes. But upon conditions. For if you ſhould find him leſs impudent, and I more preſuming; if you find him more reſpectful, and I more importunate—I don't know—the fellow is well enough for a man—Certainly we don't meet many ſuch at a horſe race in the country.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: If we ſhould find him ſo—But that's impoſſible. The firſt appearance has done my buſineſs. I'm ſeldom deceived in that.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And yet there may be many good qualities under that firſt appearance.

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Ay, when a girl finds a fellow's outſide to her taſte, ſhe then ſets about gueſſing the reſt of his furniture. With her, a ſmooth face ſtands for good ſenſe, and a genteel figure for every virtue.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, a converſation begun with a compliment to my good ſenſe won't end with a ſneer at my underſtanding?

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Pardon me, Kate. But if young Mr. Brazen can find the art of reconciling contradictions, he may pleaſe us both, perhaps.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And as one of us muſt be miſtaken, what if we go to make further diſcoveries?

sp.speaker: HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Agreed. But depend on't I'm in the right.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And depend on't I'm not much in the wrong.

div.stage: Enter TONY running in with a Caſket.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Ecod! I have got them. Here they are. My Couſin Con's necklaces, bobs and all. My mother ſhan't cheat the poor ſouls out of their fortune neither. O! my genus, is that you?

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: My dear friend, how have you managed wit your mother? I hope you have amuſed her with pretending love for your couſin, and that you are willing to be reconciled at laſt? Our horſes will be refreſhed in a ſhort time, and we ſhall ſoon be ready to ſet off.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: And here's ſomething to bear your charges by the way, (giving the caſket.) Your ſweetheart's jewels. Keep them, and hang thoſe, I ſay, that would rob you of one of them.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: But how have you procured them from your mother?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Aſk me no queſtions, and I'll tell you no fibs. I procured them by the rule of thumb. If I had not a key to every drawer in mother's bureau, how could I go to the alehouſe ſo often as I do? An honeſt man may rob himſelf of his own at any time.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: Thouſands do it every day. But to be plain with you; Miſs Neville is endeavouring to procure them from her aunt this very inſtant. If ſhe ſucceeds, it will be the moſt delicate way at leaſt of obtaining them.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Well, keep them, till you know how it will be. But I know how it will be well enough, ſhe'd as ſoon part with the only ſound tooth in her head.

sp.speaker: HASTINGS.
sp.p: But I dread the effects of her reſentment, when ſhe finds ſhe has loſt them.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Never you mind her reſentment, leave me to manage that. I don't value her reſentment the bounce of a cracker. Zounds! here they are. Morrice. Prance.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Indeed, Conſtance, you amaze me. Such a girl as you want jewels? It will be time enough for jewels, my dear, twenty years hence, when your beauty begins to want repairs.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: But what will repair beauty at forty, will certainly improve it at twenty, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p:
Yours, my dear, can admit of none. That natural bluſh is beyond a thouſand ornaments. Beſides, child, jewels are quite out at preſent. Don't you ſee half the ladies of our acquaintance, my lady, Kill day light, and Mrs. Crump, and the reſt of them,
carry their jewels to town, and bring nothing but Paſte and Marcaſites back.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: But who knows, Madam, but ſomebody that ſhall be nameleſs would like me beſt with all my little finery about me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Conſult your glaſs, my dear, and then ſee, if with ſuch a pair of eyes, you want any better ſparklers. What do you think, Tony, my dear, does your couſin Con. want any jewels, in your eyes, to ſet off her beauty.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: That's as thereafter may be.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: My dear aunt, if you knew how it would oblige me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: A parcel of old-faſhioned roſe and table-cut things. They would make you look like the court of king Solomon at a puppet-ſhew. Beſides, I believe I can't readily come at them. They may be miſſing for aught I know to the contrary.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Then why don't you tell her ſo at once, as ſhe's ſo longing for them. Tell her they're loſt. It's the only way to quiet her. Say they're loſt, and call me to bear witneſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: You know, my dear, I'm only keeping them for you. So if I ſay they're gone, you'll bear me witneſs, will you? He! he! he!

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Never fear me. Ecod! I'll ſay I ſaw them taken out with my own eyes.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: I deſire them but for a day, Madam. Juſt to be permitted to ſhew them as relicks, and then they may be lock'd up again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: To be plain with you, my dear Conſtance; if I could find them, you ſhould have them. They're miſſing, I aſſure you. Loſt, for aught I know; but we muſt have patience wherever they are.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: I'll not believe it; this is but a ſhallow pretence to deny me. I know they're too valuable to be ſo ſlightly kept, and as you are to anſwer for the loſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Don't be alarm'd, Conſtance. If they be loſt, I muſt reſtore an equivalent. But my ſon knows they are miſſing, and not to be found.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: That I can bear witneſs to. They are miſſing, and not to be found, I'll take my oath on't.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: You muſt learn reſignation, my dear; for tho' we loſe our fortune, yet we ſhould not loſe our patience. See me, how calm I am.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: Ay, people are generally calm at the misfortunes of others.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Now, I wonder a girl of your good ſenſe ſhould waſte a thought upon ſuch trumpery. We ſhall ſoon find them; and, in the mean time, you ſhall make uſe of my garnets till your jewels be found.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: I deteſt garnets.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: The moſt becoming things in the world to ſet off a clear complexion. You have often ſeen how well they look upon me. You ſhall have them.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: I diſlike them of all things. You ſhan't ſtir.—Was ever any thing ſo provoking to miſlay my own jewels, and force me to wear her trumpery.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Don't be a fool. If ſhe gives you the garnets, take what you can get. The jewels are your own already. I have ſtolen them out of her bureau, and ſhe does not know it. Fly to your ſpark, he'll tell you more of the matter. Leave me to manage her.

sp.speaker: Miſs NEVILLE.
sp.p: My dear couſin.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Vaniſh. She's here, and has miſſed them already. Zounds! how ſhe fidgets and ſpits about like a Catharine wheel.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Confuſion! thieves! robbers! We are cheated, plundered, broke open, undone.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: What's the matter, what's the matter, mamma? I hope nothing has happened to any of the good family!

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: We are robbed. My bureau has been broke open, the jewels taken out, and I'm undone.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p:
Oh! is that all? Ha, ha, ha. By the laws, I
never ſaw it better acted in my life. Ecod, I thought you was ruin'd in earneſt, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Why boy, I am ruin'd in earneſt. My bureau has been broke open, and all taken away.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Stick to that; ha, ha, ha; ſtick to that. I'll bear witneſs, you know, call me to bear witneſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: I tell you, Tony, by all that's precious, the jewels are gone, and I ſhall be ruin'd for ever.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: Sure I know they're gone, and I am to ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: My deareſt Tony, but hear me. They're gone, I ſay.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: By the laws, mamma, you make me for to laugh, ha, ha. I know who took them well enough, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Was there ever ſuch a blockhead, that can't tell the difference between jeſt and earneſt. I tell you I'm not in jeſt, booby.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: That's right, that's right: You muſt be in a bitter paſſion, and then nobody will ſuſpect either of us. I'll bear witneſs that they are gone.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Was there ever ſuch a croſs-grain'd brute, that won't hear me! Can you bear witneſs that you're no better than a fool? Was ever poor woman ſo beſet with fools on one hand, and thieves on the other.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: I can bear witneſs to that.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Bear witneſs again, you blockhead you, and I'll turn you out of the room directly. My poor niece, what will become of her! Do you laugh, you unfeeling brute, as if you enjoy'd my diſtreſs?

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: I can bear witneſs to that.

sp.speaker: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Do you inſult me, monſter? I'll teach you to vex your mother, I will.

sp.speaker: TONY.
sp.p: I can bear witneſs to that.
Enter Miſs HARDCASTLE and Maid.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: What an unaccountable creature is that brother of mine, to ſend them to the houſe as an inn, ha, ha. I don't wonder at his impudence.

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.p: But what is more, madam, the young gentleman as you paſſed by in your preſent dreſs, aſk'd me if you were the bar maid? He miſtook you for the bar maid, madam.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: Did he? Then as I live I'm reſolved to keep up the deluſion. Tell me, Pimple, how do you like my preſent dreſs. Don't you think I look ſomething like Cherry in the Beaux Stratagem?

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.p: It's the dreſs, madam, that every lady wears in the country, but when ſhe viſits or receives company.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
sp.p: And are you ſure he does not remember my face or perſon?

sp.speaker: MAID.
sp.p: Certain of it.

sp.speaker: Miſs HARDCASTLE.
